at 11:08 AM, 
mailto: 
> 
wrote: 
Mike, 
I think it would be useful to get a better understanding of your position—it would be helpful for us to know, 
for example, how much time you propose to take to evaluate matters, and whether we can provide any 
additional information that might be useful for that process of evaluation. That likely will affect our 
determination regarding the grand jury appearance, at which we would expect, were we to call to 
ask her a number of questions we would expect to argue to the court do not implicate a fifth am n m n 
privilege—i.e., that she couldn't simply blanket invoke. Would it be useful to discuss via phone? 
thanks, 
Alex. 
From: Michael Bachner 
Sent: Wednesda Jul10 2019 10:25 
To: 
Cc: 
Subject: Re: Epstein investigation

I met 
with 
and I need time to evaluate matters. Regardin the sub ena to testify before the

invoke in person or whether this communication suffices and no appertaining will be required. 
Yours truly, 
EFTA00014512

Michael Bachner

On Jul 9 2019, at 11:43 AM, 
mailto: 
> 
wrote: 
Mr. Bachner, 
Following up on our conversation earlier this morning, we wanted to provide you with the additional 
information and materials we discussed. In the first instance, so that you have full contact info for the team, 
please feel free to reach out to any of us at any time; we're all available via email or at the following phone 
numbers: 
Additionally, attached are the non-prosecution agreement, previously publicly filed in civil proceedings in 
Florida, and a blank version of our standard proffer agreement, both as discussed. 
As we mentioned, please don't hesitate to reach out with any questions, and we look forward to setting a 
time to speak again after you're able to confer with 
Assistant U.S. Attorney 
£outhern_District of New York 
<blank proffer agreement.pdf> 
<Epstein NPA, dated 2007-09-24.pdf> 
EFTA00014513
